tag-1: Starting a Business? Look to Limit Your Liability
tag-2: It takes optimism to launch your own business. But what if your optimism proves misplaced and the business gets into trouble? As a sole proprietor, you would be personally responsible for the liabilities of the business. That means creditors could come after your home and your personal investments.
tag-3: Because of that risk, many business owners adopt one of two basic legal structures, the S-Corp or the LLC, which can be less costly and complicated to operate than the C-Corp structure favored by larger companies. The Subchapter S Corporation, named after a section of the tax code, is designed for smaller companies that need liability protection. It offers tax advantages not enjoyed by LLCs.
tag-4: An S-Corp, however, is limited to no more than 100 shareholders and involves more onerous initial and ongoing legal requirements. The IRS refers to the S-Corp as a "pass-through" entity in which all profits and losses pass through to the owners, who report this information on their personal tax returns. This can be a plus for new businesses, since they often lose money in the early years and you can offset those losses against personal income.
tag-5: The LLC, or limited liability company, is also a pass-through entity in which profits and losses flow through to the individual investors, who are called members. Like the S-Corp, members of an LLC typically aren't personally liable for its debts or other obligations. But unlike the S-Corp, there is no limit to the number of members. Which is right for you, an LLC or S-Corp? Before choosing, consider consulting an attorney with experience in this area.
